metadata.title: An Initial Functional and Security Coverage Analysis of AWS Security Agent Against the OWASP Top 10 (2025)
metadata.author: Ivan Bylina

abstract: This study presents an initial functional and security coverage analysis of AWS Security Agent, a newly introduced AWS-managed, GenAI-enabled security assessment service designed to support design review, code analysis, and penetration testing within the software development lifecycle. The evaluation is based on empirical testing of the service, supplemented by a systematic review of publicly available AWS documentation. The study examines three core capabilities: design security review, code security review and on-demand penetration testing, evaluates their implementation characteristics, operational limitations, and coverage of the OWASP Top 10 (2025) application security risks. Results indicate support for context-aware, multi-step penetration testing and real-time pull-request analysis, with effective detection of injection vulnerabilities. OWASP Top 10 coverage analysis reveals significant variation across risk categories, with strongest coverage in injection vulnerabilities and access control, moderate coverage in security misconfiguration and insecure design, and weakest coverage in software supply chain security, cryptographic validation beyond TLS checks, and security logging. However, the service is limited to a web-based interface, lacks CLI or API access, and exhibits partial OWASP coverage overall, with significant gaps in software supply chain security, cryptographic validation, and security logging. This work provides an objective, practitioner-focused assessment of current capabilities and limitations and does not constitute a security certification or endorsement of the service.

sections.title: Introduction
paragraphs: Application security teams must secure applications as they evolve through design, coding and deployment. Traditional security reviews and penetration tests are typically manual and scheduled infrequently, leading to gaps and late findings. AWS introduced the "Security Agent" as a AI agent designed to embed security into each stage of the software development lifecycle [1]. The service was first publicly announced at AWS re:Invent 2025, held December 1–5, 2025, signaling AWS’s intent to operationalize generative AI–assisted security reviews within mainstream development workflows [2]. The agent provides design reviews, code security reviews and multi‑step penetration testing within a centralized web interface, aiming to make expert‑level security assessments available on demand and at scale [1]. The official documentation confirms that AWS Security Agent operates across AWS, on-premise, hybrid, multicloud, and SaaS environments [1] and consolidates findings from design, code and penetration tests in one place.

subsections.title: Design Security Review
paragraphs: The design review capability allows security teams to upload design documents (architectural diagrams, system designs, data‑flow diagrams and threat models) and assess them against organizational security requirements. The official AWS documentation confirms that AWS Security Agent shifts security left by providing real-time security feedback on design documents and assessing compliance with organizational security requirements before any code is written [1]. Security teams upload documents through the web application and receive remediation guidance to prioritize findings [1]. The agent supports custom security requirements-teams can define description, applicability, compliance criteria and remediation guidance for each requirement. During testing, it was noted that custom requirements are defined through free‑text fields limited to 500 characters for descriptions and 10 000 characters for other fields, and the underlying model interprets them, which may change over time. The design review runs entirely in the external web application opened from the AWS console. Supported formats include markdown, PDF and common architectural diagram formats, but uploading is done manually; there is currently no CLI or API to automate submissions.

subsections.title: Code Security Review
paragraphs: Code review analyzes pull requests in source control repositories against security requirements and the OWASP Top 10. The official AWS documentation states that AWS Security Agent proactively secures applications by analyzing pull requests against organizational security requirements and common vulnerabilities like missing input validation and SQL injection risks [1]. Developers receive remediation guidance directly in their GitHub workflow [1]. The official AWS documentation for reviewing code security findings in GitHub confirms that code review is triggered when a pull request is marked as "Ready for review" in repositories where code review capability is enabled, and that draft pull requests are not analyzed [3]. The AWS News Feed article notes that the agent's code review checks GitHub pull requests for OWASP Top Ten vulnerabilities and policy violations [4]. The official AWS documentation only mentions GitHub integration [3]. During testing, it was observed that the public preview integrates only with GitHub via a GitHub App, supports up to 20 private repositories per integration [5] and does not scan public repositories. Pull requests are the only unit of analysis - full repository scans are not supported. Remediation guidance and suggested fixes are posted directly in the developer's workflow, but customizing the checks beyond the defined security requirements is limited.

subsections.title: On‑Demand Penetration Testing
paragraphs: AWS Security Agent's penetration testing capability performs multi‑step attack simulations on web applications. The official AWS documentation confirms that AWS Security Agent delivers on-demand penetration testing by deploying specialized AI agents to discover, validate, report and remediate security vulnerabilities through tailored multi-step attack scenarios [1]. The agent understands the application's context by analyzing source code and documentation to identify and exploit vulnerabilities that automated security scanning tools cannot find [1]. It documents findings with impact analysis, reproducible attack paths, and creates pull requests with ready-to-implement code fixes [1]. The official AWS documentation for creating penetration tests specifies that only verified domains can be included in penetration tests and that VPC configuration is only required for testing private applications hosted within an Amazon Virtual Private Cloud [6]. It is promoted as automating context‑aware penetration tests that scale across many applications [4]. The National CIO Review notes that the agent continuously scans workloads for vulnerabilities and performs penetration testing tailored to the application's structure and intended behavior, eliminating the need to wait for human‑led assessments [7]. The ComputerWeekly report adds that the agent understands the design, code and security requirements of a workload and can create a customised attack plan to expose vulnerabilities before an application reaches production [8]. During testing, it was noted that all penetration tests require a verified domain (with DNS TXT record) [6], and for private applications hosted within a VPC, additional VPC configuration is also required [6]. Tests can include contextual artifacts such as API documentation, threat models, source code archives and GitHub repositories. Only HTTP/HTTPS targets are supported; custom ports and other protocols are not. The agent creates multiple action groups (information disclosure, business logic vulnerabilities, unrestricted resource consumption, authentication bypass, etc.), uses static analysis tasks to inspect the source, and then launches validators that exploit vulnerabilities to minimise false positives. The risk categories available for testing include arbitrary file upload, code injection, command injection, cross‑site scripting (XSS), insecure direct object references, JSON Web Token vulnerabilities, local file inclusion, path traversal, privilege escalation, server‑side request forgery (SSRF), server‑side template injection, SQL injection and XML external entity attacks.

subsections.title: Setup and Permissions
paragraphs: AWS Security Agent was tested using a read‑only IAM user with permissions gradually added. The web console provided clear error messages for many missing permissions, but some errors required examining logs to identify the missing IAM policies. The agent can only be enabled via the AWS console; there is no CLI, CloudFormation template or SDK interface for configuration-making it a click‑ops process. All interactions occur via a web console with no CLI or official AWS CLI commands available. The preview is available only in the us‑east‑1 region and requires creation of an "Agent Space". Connecting GitHub triggers installation of a GitHub App with repository access restricted to selected or all repositories.

subsections.title: Design Review Findings
paragraphs: The design review accepts supported file types via manual upload. In some highly regulated environments, uploading documents through a web UI may be blocked, limiting adoption. The service was tested with basic design documents, and it was observed that policies such as "Secure by Default, Tenant Isolation, Secret Protection, Trusted Cryptography, Audit Logging, Authorization, Log Protection, Information Protection, Privileged Access and Authentication" were applied. When the design intentionally violated requirements, the agent failed corresponding policies; when the design mentioned the required topics, half of the policies were marked as needing more details. Uploading irrelevant documents led to all policies being marked not applicable. Custom security requirements worked as expected; a test rule designed to block specific fictional terms was triggered when related keywords appeared in variable names. However, the manual upload process and lack of automation make it difficult to integrate design review into CI/CD pipelines. During testing, it was noted that the underlying language model performing analysis is not documented; thus the behaviour may change as models are updated. This lack of determinism makes it difficult to rely on the tool for strict policy enforcement.

subsections.title: Code Review Findings
paragraphs: Code review worked only for private GitHub repositories configured through the GitHub App. Pull requests were evaluated against the same security requirements used for design review and against common vulnerability patterns. The agent does not analyze entire codebases-only changes in pull requests. Custom security requirements could be reused across design and code reviews. There is no support for public repositories, and integration with other source control systems (Bitbucket, GitLab, CodeCommit) was not present in the preview. The tool offers two modes: one to check custom security requirements and another to detect "security vulnerability findings" that resemble the output of Amazon CodeGuru Reviewer; the latter uses rules similar to open‑source tools like Bandit and Infer.

subsections.title: Penetration Testing Findings
paragraphs: To start a penetration test, users must verify ownership of a target domain by creating a DNS TXT record. Automatic verification via Route53 often fails, requiring manual DNS record creation. The penetration testing workflow opens in an external web application separate from the main AWS console. Tests can target an external domain or run from within a VPC; however, the tool does not support VPCs using the 10.0.0.0/16 CIDR because it conflicts with the agent's addressing. Custom ports and non‑HTTP protocols are unsupported; specifying a port in the URL causes the run to start but never succeeds. When a VPC is selected, outbound internet connectivity is required even to fetch GitHub context. Penetration tests also request CloudWatch log groups as destinations, but pre‑created log groups sometimes fail validation due to undocumented naming conventions; leaving the field blank allows the agent to create log groups automatically. Contextual resources can include S3 buckets (only plaintext API documentation, threat models or zipped source code archives), GitHub repositories and plain‑text credentials via the UI. Lambda functions and Secrets Manager entries are used solely to provide authentication credentials. During scanning, the agent builds a sitemap, performs static analysis of frameworks, business logic, important flows and misconfigurations, and then launches validator tasks for risk categories such as arbitrary file upload, code and command injection, XSS, IDOR, JWT vulnerabilities, local file inclusion, path traversal, privilege escalation, SSRF, SSTI, SQL injection and XML external entity attacks. The agent uses tools like testssl.sh to check TLS configurations. It produces detailed findings with CVSS scores, exploit steps and remediation guidance. However, exploitation of complex vulnerabilities that require running external tooling or interacting with local services (labelled "Hard" during testing) is not supported. Custom exploitation code added to the context caused hallucinations - e.g., the agent incorrectly marked a vulnerability as CVE‑2021‑21311 based on proof for CVE‑2018‑7667. Additionally, the service prohibits creation of custom infrastructure or use of localhost services, limiting validation of sophisticated scenarios.

sections.title: Limitations and Gaps
paragraphs: The following tables summarise limitations identified during testing and map them to available documentation where possible. Table 1 lists limitations mentioned in official AWS sources (blogs and documentation) and confirmed through testing. Table 2 lists limitations observed during testing that are not mentioned in the sources reviewed.

tables.caption: Table 1 – Documented limitations
rows: Service is in preview and available only in US East (N. Virginia). AWS News Feed notes that AWS Security Agent is free during the preview and available only in the US East (N. Virginia) region [4].

Access is through a web‑based interface with no CLI, API, or scheduling capabilities. Official AWS documentation states that the agent provides design reviews, code security reviews and multi‑step penetration testing within a centralized web interface [1]. Official AWS documentation on security considerations explicitly states that "AWS Security Agent does not have public APIs or the ability to schedule the pen test runs" [9]. Configuration, design uploads, repository integration and test execution can only be performed via the console and external web app; there is no AWS CLI or SDK support. Tests must be triggered manually via the console; cannot integrate penetration tests into CI/CD pipelines or scheduled assessments.

Code review analyzes GitHub pull requests rather than full repositories. AWS News Feed states that code review checks GitHub pull requests for OWASP Top Ten vulnerabilities and policy violations [4]. The preview only reviews pull requests on private repositories; it does not scan entire codebases.

Only GitHub integration available for code review. Official AWS documentation for reviewing code security findings in GitHub states that code review is triggered when a pull request is marked as "Ready for review" in repositories where code review capability is enabled, and only GitHub is mentioned throughout the documentation [3]. The documentation does not mention support for other source control systems. The preview only supports GitHub integration; other SCM systems (GitLab, Bitbucket, CodeCommit) are not available.

Limit of 20 integrated resources per integration. Official AWS documentation on Service Quotas specifies that integrated resources per integration are limited to 20 per integration, and this quota is not adjustable [5]. Large organizations may have more repositories than allowed and must manage multiple integrations or agent spaces.

Limit of 20 integrations per account per region. Official AWS documentation on Service Quotas specifies that integrations are limited to 20 per account per region, and this quota is not adjustable [5]. Organizations with many repositories may need to create multiple agent spaces or request quota increases.

Limit of 20 custom security requirements per account per region. Official AWS documentation on Service Quotas specifies that custom security requirements are limited to 20 per account per region, and this quota is not adjustable [5]. Organizations with extensive security policies may need to prioritize which requirements to configure.

Concurrent pentest runs limited to 5 per account per region. Official AWS documentation on Service Quotas specifies that concurrent pentest runs are limited to 5 per account per region, though this quota is adjustable [5]. Multiple penetration tests can run simultaneously, but the limit may require scheduling for organizations with high testing needs.

Public repositories unsupported. Official AWS documentation on security best practices explicitly states that "AWS Security Agent does not provide code security guidance for public repositories. It will not comment on public repositories or open-source projects where security findings would be publicly visible" [10]. Only private repositories can be scanned, preventing open-source projects from using the service.

VPC CIDR range 10.0.0.0/16 not supported. Official AWS documentation on connecting agent to private VPC resources explicitly states that "For VPC penetration tests, VPC CIDR ranges that overlap with the 10.0.0.0/16 range are currently not supported" [11]. Common corporate VPC ranges conflict with the agent; penetration tests using VPCs with this CIDR range will fail.

VPC must have outbound internet connectivity. Official AWS documentation on infrastructure security states that "AWS Security Agent requires internet access to perform penetration testing on target applications and for control plane operations" [12]. Penetration tests inside a VPC fail if there is no outbound connectivity.

tables.caption: Table 2 – Limitations observed in the preview not documented in sources
rows: Design review and code review rely on manual uploads and cannot fetch from VPC or internal file shares. Organizations with strict egress controls or blocked uploads cannot use the feature; files must be manually uploaded to an external web app.

Only HTTP/HTTPS targets supported; custom ports unsupported. Applications listening on non‑standard ports or protocols cannot be tested; specifying a port in the URL causes the test to hang or fail without clear error messages.

Risk of hallucinated vulnerabilities when additional exploit code is provided. The agent may misattribute vulnerabilities (e.g., marking CVE‑2021‑21311 validated using proof for CVE‑2018‑7667), reducing confidence in findings.

Complex exploitation scenarios requiring custom tooling or local services unsupported. "Hard" vulnerability exploitation cannot be validated; local or external attack tools cannot be executed within the agent's environment.
Underlying language model and its updates are not exposed. Behaviour may change over time; results may not be reproducible and cannot be tuned for determinism.

paragraphsAfter: Table 2 summarises limitations observed in the preview that are not mentioned in the documentation reviewed.

sections.title: OWASP Top 10 Coverage Evaluation
paragraphs: AWS Security Agent claims to detect OWASP Top Ten vulnerabilities in its code review and penetration testing features [4]. The OWASP Top 10:2025 lists the most critical web‑application security risks, including Broken Access Control (A01), Security Misconfiguration (A02), Software Supply Chain Failures (A03), Cryptographic Failures (A04), Injection (A05), Insecure Design (A06), Authentication Failures (A07), Software or Data Integrity Failures (A08), Security Logging and Alerting Failures (A09) and Mishandling of Exceptional Conditions (A10) [13]. Table 3 evaluates coverage of these categories based on the documented and observed capabilities of AWS Security Agent. Where coverage is partial or absent, additional controls are recommended.

subsections.title: Coverage Visualization
paragraphs: Figure 1 presents an area chart visualizing the OWASP Top 10 coverage percentages across all risk categories, illustrating the significant variation in coverage from complete coverage in injection vulnerabilities to no coverage in software supply chain failures.

chart.caption: Figure 1 – OWASP Top 10 (2025) Coverage by AWS Security Agent
labels: A08: Software or Data Integrity Failures
A09: Security Logging and Alerting Failures

table.caption: Table 3 – OWASP Top 10 (2025) coverage by AWS Security Agent*
table.note: * The evaluation was conducted against a sample simplified applications with known vulnerabilities. As a result, additional weaknesses or architectural limitations commonly observed in real-world, large-scale applications may not be represented. Analysis of such scenarios is outside the scope of this research.
rows: A01: Broken Access Control
Least privilege enforcement
Covered

Description: The service conducts authenticated runtime testing to verify that authorization decisions are consistently enforced at runtime, bound to server-side session context rather than user-supplied identifiers. The service verifies that unauthenticated or unauthorized requests are reliably rejected.

Evidence: Evidence from penetration test runs demonstrates comprehensive coverage through dedicated action groups: "Privilege escalation" with validator tasks. Findings include privilege escalation vulnerabilities identifying that any authenticated user can access admin functionality, violating least privilege.

Limitations: To enable comprehensive authorization assurance and complete privilege boundary validation, it is important to provide the agent with access to application source code, authentication information, API documentation with full endpoint and role-mapping information. Without this context, validation of complex authorization logic, multi-role privilege escalation paths, and conditional access controls remains inherently limited.
A01: Broken Access Control
Access control bypass prevention
Covered
Description: The service conducts authenticated runtime testing to identify access control bypass vulnerabilities through unauthorized parameter manipulation and HTTP method tampering.
Evidence: Evidence from penetration test runs demonstrates detection of authentication bypass vulnerabilities demonstrating bypassing access control through parameter tampering.

Limitations: To enable comprehensive authorization assurance and complete privilege boundary validation, it is important to provide the agent with access to application source code, authentication information, API documentation with full endpoint and role-mapping information. Without this context, validation of complex authorization logic, multi-role privilege escalation paths, and conditional access controls remains inherently limited.
A01: Broken Access Control
IDOR protection
Covered
Description: The service conducts authenticated runtime testing to identify insecure direct object references (IDOR) vulnerabilities.

Evidence: Evidence from penetration test runs demonstrates comprehensive coverage through dedicated action groups: "Insecure direct object reference" with validator tasks. IDOR vulnerabilities demonstrating insecure direct object reference detection.

Limitations: To enable comprehensive authorization assurance and complete privilege boundary validation, it is important to provide the agent with access to application source code, authentication information, API documentation with full endpoint and role-mapping information. Without this context, validation of complex authorization logic, multi-role privilege escalation paths, and conditional access controls remains inherently limited.
A01: Broken Access Control
Missing access controls detection
Covered
Description: The service conducts authenticated runtime testing to identify missing access controls and baseline role-based access enforcement.
Evidence: Evidence from penetration test runs demonstrates comprehensive coverage through dedicated action groups with validator tasks.

Limitations: To enable comprehensive authorization assurance and complete privilege boundary validation, it is important to provide the agent with access to application source code, authentication information, API documentation with full endpoint and role-mapping information. Without this context, validation of complex authorization logic, multi-role privilege escalation paths, and conditional access controls remains inherently limited.
A01: Broken Access Control
Privilege escalation prevention
Covered
Description: The service conducts authenticated runtime testing to identify privilege escalation vulnerabilities.

Evidence: Evidence from penetration test runs demonstrates comprehensive coverage through dedicated action groups: "Privilege escalation" with validator tasks. Findings include privilege escalation vulnerabilities identifying that any authenticated user can access admin functionality, violating least privilege.

Limitations: To enable comprehensive authorization assurance and complete privilege boundary validation, it is important to provide the agent with access to application source code, authentication information, API documentation with full endpoint and role-mapping information. Without this context, validation of complex authorization logic, multi-role privilege escalation paths, and conditional access controls remains inherently limited.
A01: Broken Access Control
Force browsing protection
Covered
Description: The service conducts authenticated runtime testing to identify force browsing vulnerabilities where unauthorized access to resources is possible.
Evidence: Evidence from penetration test runs demonstrates comprehensive coverage through dedicated action groups with validator tasks.

Limitations: To enable comprehensive authorization assurance and complete privilege boundary validation, it is important to provide the agent with access to application source code, authentication information, API documentation with full endpoint and role-mapping information. Without this context, validation of complex authorization logic, multi-role privilege escalation paths, and conditional access controls remains inherently limited.
A01: Broken Access Control
Metadata manipulation testing (JWT, cookies, hidden fields)
Partial
Description: The service tests for metadata manipulation through dedicated "Json web token vulnerabilities" action groups and session manipulation tests (e.g., session fixation vulnerabilities).
Evidence: Evidence from penetration test runs demonstrates dedicated action groups for metadata manipulation testing.

Limitations: The service provides comprehensive testing capabilities for all metadata manipulation vectors (cookie tampering, hidden field manipulation, JWT invalidation abuse) when provided with full application context. To enable comprehensive authorization assurance and complete privilege boundary validation, the service can utilize application source code, authentication information, and API documentation with full endpoint and role-mapping information when provided. The "Partial" status reflects that comprehensive testing requires providing this context information through the service's available functionality.
A01: Broken Access Control
CORS misconfiguration detection
Partial
Description: The service may detect CORS misconfigurations through network scanning and TLS/SSL validation tools.
Evidence: The service may detect CORS misconfigurations through network scanning and TLS/SSL validation tools (testssl.sh version 3.2.2) in the "Network scanner" action group.

Limitations: Comprehensive CORS testing requires specific validation of cross-origin access controls, including testing of allowed origins, credentials handling, and preflight request validation, which may not be explicitly tested in all scenarios without dedicated CORS-specific test cases. To enable comprehensive authorization assurance and complete privilege boundary validation, it is important to provide the agent with access to application source code, authentication information, API documentation with full endpoint and role-mapping information.
A02: Security Misconfiguration
Security headers validation
Covered

Description: The service conducts static analysis and penetration tests that include dedicated "Security Misconfiguration" action groups. The agent executes a dedicated Security Misconfiguration action group with validator tasks.

Evidence: Evidence from multiple penetration test runs demonstrates comprehensive coverage: Detection of missing security headers (Content-Security-Policy, X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, Strict-Transport-Security, Referrer-Policy, X-XSS-Protection, Permissions-Policy) using testssl.sh (version 3.2.2) with direct HTTP validation.
Limitations: None identified for this specific requirement.
A02: Security Misconfiguration
Error message handling
Covered
Description: The service conducts static analysis and penetration tests that include dedicated "Security Misconfiguration" action groups.
Evidence: Evidence from multiple penetration test runs demonstrates detection of missing account existence validation and unhandled error exposure.
Limitations: None identified for this specific requirement.
A02: Security Misconfiguration
Framework settings validation
Covered
Description: The service conducts static analysis and penetration tests that include dedicated "Security Misconfiguration" action groups.

Evidence: Evidence from multiple penetration test runs demonstrates identification of Flask debug mode enabled in production and missing CSRF protection configuration in Flask-WTF applications through framework-specific analysis.

Limitations: Explicit detection of disabled security features in upgraded systems requires historical comparison of security feature configurations before and after upgrades, which is not clearly demonstrated. The service focuses on identifying active misconfigurations in the current state rather than assessing whether security features were intentionally disabled during system upgrades or whether backward compatibility decisions led to insecure configurations.
A02: Security Misconfiguration
Container hardening
Partial
Description: The service conducts static analysis and penetration tests that include dedicated "Security Misconfiguration" action groups.

Evidence: Evidence from multiple penetration test runs demonstrates static analysis of Dockerfile configurations identifying root user execution, embedded database files, and insecure network binding.

Limitations: The service can inspect Dockerfile configurations through static analysis, but cannot detect configuration drift or validate the actual configuration of the running application. This limitation exists because the service only has access to the application over HTTP/HTTPS and cannot directly inspect container runtime configurations, environment variables, or verify that the running container matches the Dockerfile specifications.
A02: Security Misconfiguration
Unnecessary features detection
Covered
Description: The service conducts static analysis and penetration tests that include dedicated "Security Misconfiguration" action groups.
Evidence: Evidence from multiple penetration test runs demonstrates comprehensive coverage through static analysis and framework-specific analysis.
Limitations: None identified for this specific requirement.
A02: Security Misconfiguration
Default credentials testing
Not covered

Description: The service conducts static analysis and penetration tests that include dedicated "Security Misconfiguration" action groups, but does not explicitly test for default accounts and unchanged passwords.
Evidence: No evidence of default credentials testing found in penetration test runs.
Limitations: The service does not explicitly test for default accounts and unchanged passwords, and does not evaluate backward compatibility decisions.
A02: Security Misconfiguration
Cloud permissions assessment
Not covered

Description: The service provides comprehensive coverage for application stack security hardening, including container configuration analysis. However, the service does not assess cloud service permissions.
Evidence: No evidence of cloud permissions assessment found in penetration test runs.

Limitations: The service does not assess cloud service permissions (e.g., IAM policies, S3 bucket permissions, security groups, VPC configurations). This limitation means that cloud-native security misconfigurations at the infrastructure layer are not evaluated, requiring organizations to use dedicated IaC security scanning tools alongside AWS Security Agent.
A02: Security Misconfiguration
Infrastructure as code validation
Not covered

Description: The service provides comprehensive coverage for application stack security hardening, including container configuration analysis. However, the service does not assess infrastructure as code files.
Evidence: No evidence of infrastructure as code validation found in penetration test runs.

Limitations: The service does not assess infrastructure as code (IaC) files (e.g., Terraform, CloudFormation, Ansible) or cloud service permissions (e.g., IAM policies, S3 bucket permissions, security groups, VPC configurations). This limitation means that cloud-native security misconfigurations at the infrastructure layer are not evaluated, requiring organizations to use dedicated IaC security scanning tools alongside AWS Security Agent.
A03: Software Supply Chain Failures
Dependency manifest file scanning
Not covered
Description: AWS Security Agent does not inspect third‑party dependencies or SBOMs. It focuses on design documents, pull requests and runtime behaviour rather than supply‑chain risks.

Evidence: Empirical validation from multiple penetration test runs confirms that code scanner tasks analyze frameworks, important flows, and business logic patterns but do not scan dependency manifest files. No findings related to dependency vulnerabilities, outdated packages, or supply chain risks were identified in any examined pentest runs.

Limitations: The service does not scan dependency manifest files, check versions against vulnerability databases, generate SBOMs, or validate dependency versions against known CVEs.

Additional Notes: Organizations should use dedicated Software Composition Analysis (SCA) tools alongside AWS Security Agent to address Software Supply Chain Failures requirements.
A03: Software Supply Chain Failures
Version validation against vulnerability databases
Not covered
Description: AWS Security Agent does not inspect third‑party dependencies or SBOMs. It focuses on design documents, pull requests and runtime behaviour rather than supply‑chain risks.

Evidence: Empirical validation from multiple penetration test runs confirms that code scanner tasks do not check versions against vulnerability databases. The service identifies framework types (e.g., Flask, Werkzeug) through static analysis but does not validate versions.

Limitations: The service does not scan dependency manifest files, check versions against vulnerability databases, generate SBOMs, or validate dependency versions against known CVEs.

Additional Notes: Organizations should use dedicated Software Composition Analysis (SCA) tools alongside AWS Security Agent to address Software Supply Chain Failures requirements.
A03: Software Supply Chain Failures
SBOM generation and validation
Not covered
Description: AWS Security Agent does not inspect third‑party dependencies or SBOMs. It focuses on design documents, pull requests and runtime behaviour rather than supply‑chain risks.

Evidence: Empirical validation from multiple penetration test runs confirms that code scanner tasks do not generate SBOMs. Code review analyzes pull requests for security vulnerabilities in code patterns but does not validate SBOMs.

Limitations: The service does not scan dependency manifest files, check versions against vulnerability databases, generate SBOMs, or validate dependency versions against known CVEs.

Additional Notes: Organizations should use dedicated Software Composition Analysis (SCA) tools alongside AWS Security Agent to address Software Supply Chain Failures requirements.
A03: Software Supply Chain Failures
CVE checking for dependencies
Not covered
Description: AWS Security Agent does not inspect third‑party dependencies or SBOMs. It focuses on design documents, pull requests and runtime behaviour rather than supply‑chain risks.

Evidence: Empirical validation from multiple penetration test runs confirms that the service identifies framework types (e.g., Flask, Werkzeug) through static analysis but does not check for known CVEs.

Limitations: The service does not scan dependency manifest files, check versions against vulnerability databases, generate SBOMs, or validate dependency versions against known CVEs.

Additional Notes: Organizations should use dedicated Software Composition Analysis (SCA) tools alongside AWS Security Agent to address Software Supply Chain Failures requirements.
A03: Software Supply Chain Failures
Supply chain security policy enforcement
Not covered
Description: AWS Security Agent does not inspect third‑party dependencies or SBOMs. It focuses on design documents, pull requests and runtime behaviour rather than supply‑chain risks.
Evidence: Design reviews assess application security requirements but do not include supply chain security policies.

Limitations: The service does not scan dependency manifest files, check versions against vulnerability databases, generate SBOMs, or validate dependency versions against known CVEs.

Additional Notes: Organizations should use dedicated Software Composition Analysis (SCA) tools alongside AWS Security Agent to address Software Supply Chain Failures requirements.
A03: Software Supply Chain Failures
Trusted repository consumption validation
Not covered
Description: AWS Security Agent does not inspect third‑party dependencies or SBOMs. It focuses on design documents, pull requests and runtime behaviour rather than supply‑chain risks.
Evidence: No evidence of trusted repository consumption validation found in penetration test runs.

Limitations: The service does not scan dependency manifest files, check versions against vulnerability databases, generate SBOMs, or validate dependency versions against known CVEs.

Additional Notes: Organizations should use dedicated Software Composition Analysis (SCA) tools alongside AWS Security Agent to address Software Supply Chain Failures requirements.
A04: Cryptographic Failures
TLS/SSL configuration validation
Covered

Description: AWS Security Agent provides coverage for TLS/SSL configuration validation. The service includes a dedicated TLS scanner using testssl.sh (version 3.2.2) that validates TLS/SSL protocol versions, cipher suites, server certificates, and trust chains.
Evidence: The service validates TLS/SSL configurations using testssl.sh (version 3.2.2), which checks for weak protocol versions (e.g., SSL 2.0, SSL 3.0, TLS 1.0, TLS 1.1) and weak cipher suites.

Limitations: None identified for this specific requirement.

Additional Notes: Design review can enforce "Trusted Cryptography Best Practices" organizational requirements.
A04: Cryptographic Failures
Weak cryptographic algorithm detection
Partial
Description: AWS Security Agent provides partial coverage for weak cryptographic algorithm detection.

Evidence: The service can enforce cryptographic policies through design review ("Trusted Cryptography Best Practices" organizational requirements) and validates TLS/SSL configurations using testssl.sh (version 3.2.2), which checks for weak protocol versions and weak cipher suites. However, the service does not automatically detect weak cryptographic algorithms in application code (e.g., DES, RC4, MD5, SHA1 used in application logic, not just TLS).

Limitations: The service does not automatically detect weak cryptographic algorithms beyond TLS checks (e.g., DES, RC4, MD5, SHA1 in application code). The code scanner analyzes source code patterns but does not specifically analyze cryptographic primitives or algorithm choices in application code beyond TLS/SSL configuration.

Additional Notes: Organizations should use dedicated cryptographic analysis tools alongside AWS Security Agent to address requirements related to encryption implementation details, hash function validation, and cryptographic randomness.
A04: Cryptographic Failures
Cryptographic primitive analysis
Not covered
Description: AWS Security Agent does not automatically analyze cryptographic primitives.
Evidence: The code scanner analyzes source code patterns but does not specifically analyze cryptographic primitives or algorithm choices in application code beyond TLS/SSL configuration.

Limitations: The service does not automatically analyze cryptographic primitives, detect insecure algorithms beyond TLS checks (e.g., DES, RC4, MD5, SHA1 in application code), validate initialization vectors or encryption modes, check for deprecated hash functions, assess cryptographic randomness, or analyze cryptographic error messages and side channel vulnerabilities.

Additional Notes: Organizations should use dedicated cryptographic analysis tools alongside AWS Security Agent to address requirements related to encryption implementation details, hash function validation, and cryptographic randomness.
A04: Cryptographic Failures
Initialization vector validation
Not covered
Description: AWS Security Agent does not validate initialization vectors.
Evidence: No evidence of initialization vector validation found in penetration test runs.

Limitations: The service does not automatically analyze cryptographic primitives, detect insecure algorithms beyond TLS checks (e.g., DES, RC4, MD5, SHA1 in application code), validate initialization vectors or encryption modes, check for deprecated hash functions, assess cryptographic randomness, or analyze cryptographic error messages and side channel vulnerabilities.

Additional Notes: Organizations should use dedicated cryptographic analysis tools alongside AWS Security Agent to address requirements related to encryption implementation details, hash function validation, and cryptographic randomness.

Additional Notes: Organizations should use dedicated cryptographic analysis tools alongside AWS Security Agent to address requirements related to encryption implementation details, hash function validation, and cryptographic randomness.

A06: Insecure Design
Requirements gathering validation
Partial

Description: Design review assesses architectural documents against security requirements. The service supports secure development lifecycle practices through early design reviews, continuous code reviews, and runtime penetration testing.

Evidence: The service provides design review capabilities that assess uploaded architectural documents against security requirements (e.g., Secure by Default Best Practices, Tenant Isolation Best Practices, Authorization Best Practices), enabling validation of requirements gathering practices.

Limitations: Coverage is dependent on design documents being manually uploaded by users. If the upload process is skipped or documents are not provided, the service cannot assess requirements gathering or resource management practices. Additionally, the service may not detect complex insecure designs if security requirements are incomplete or if architectural flaws are not explicitly documented in the uploaded design documents.

Additional Notes: The service focuses on detecting implemented insecure designs through runtime testing rather than preventing insecure designs during the design phase.

A07: Authentication Failures
Session management validation
Covered
Description: Penetration tests detect session management flaws. Design reviews can enforce "Authentication Best Practices" including secure password policies.

Evidence: Evidence from penetration test runs demonstrates detection of session fixation vulnerabilities (High severity) detecting session identifier reuse after successful login; missing logout functionality (Medium severity).

Limitations: Comprehensive testing of all session identifier exposure vectors (URLs, hidden fields, client-side storage) may require full application context to identify all session management mechanisms used by the application.

Additional Notes: The service detects session management vulnerabilities including session fixation (High severity), which demonstrates detection of session identifier reuse after successful login. While the specific finding relates to session regeneration rather than session identifier exposure in URLs, the service's session management testing would likely detect insecure session identifier storage.

A09: Security Logging and Alerting Failures
Auditable events logging (logins, failed logins, high-value transactions)
Partial
Description: The service provides minimal coverage for Security Logging and Alerting Failures. The service can enforce "Audit Logging Best Practices" through design reviews.

Evidence: The service detects missing or inadequate audit logging for auditable events (logins, failed logins, high-value transactions) through static code analysis and penetration testing. Evidence from penetration test runs demonstrates detection of missing or inadequate audit logging through findings identifying missing authentication event logging, authorization decision logging, administrative action logging, and missing transaction metadata required for forensics.

Limitations: The service does not actively test whether applications log these events consistently or validate log completeness. The service identifies that logging is missing but does not verify that logging works correctly when implemented. The service does not assess whether applications generate sufficient security logs.

Additional Notes: The service detects missing or inadequate audit logging through static code analysis and penetration testing, but does not validate that logging works correctly when implemented.

Additional Notes: The service focuses on detecting missing logging but does not assess log monitoring capabilities.
A09: Security Logging and Alerting Failures
Alerting threshold validation
Not covered
Description: The service provides minimal coverage for Security Logging and Alerting Failures.
Evidence: No evidence of alerting threshold validation found in penetration test runs.

Limitations: The service does not assess whether alerting thresholds are appropriate, whether penetration testing triggers alerts, whether real-time attack detection works, or whether alert use cases and playbooks are adequate.

Additional Notes: The service focuses on detecting missing logging but does not assess alerting threshold configuration.
A09: Security Logging and Alerting Failures
Real-time attack detection
Not covered
Description: The service provides minimal coverage for Security Logging and Alerting Failures.
Evidence: No evidence of real-time attack detection assessment found in penetration test runs.

Limitations: The service does not assess whether real-time attack detection works, whether penetration testing triggers alerts, or whether alert use cases and playbooks are adequate.

Additional Notes: The service focuses on detecting missing logging but does not assess real-time attack detection capabilities.
A09: Security Logging and Alerting Failures
Alert use cases and playbooks adequacy
Not covered
Description: The service provides minimal coverage for Security Logging and Alerting Failures.
Evidence: No evidence of alert use cases and playbooks assessment found in penetration test runs.

Limitations: The service does not assess whether alert use cases and playbooks are adequate, whether penetration testing triggers alerts, or whether real-time attack detection works.

Additional Notes: The service focuses on detecting missing logging but does not assess alert use cases or playbooks.
A10: Mishandling of Exceptional Conditions
Exception handling validation
Covered
Description: AWS Security Agent provides coverage for exception handling validation. The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis.
Evidence: Evidence from penetration test runs demonstrates detection of improper error handling through findings identifying exceptions that are not handled close to where they occur.

Limitations: None identified for this specific requirement.

Additional Notes: The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis, testing invalid inputs and exception scenarios through multiple action groups.
A10: Mishandling of Exceptional Conditions
Error response leakage prevention
Covered
Description: AWS Security Agent provides coverage for error response leakage prevention. The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis.
Evidence: Evidence from penetration test runs demonstrates detection of improper error handling through findings identifying error responses that leak sensitive information or enable enumeration.

Limitations: None identified for this specific requirement.

Additional Notes: The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis, testing invalid inputs and exception scenarios.
A10: Mishandling of Exceptional Conditions
Resource exhaustion prevention
Covered
Description: AWS Security Agent provides coverage for resource exhaustion prevention. The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis.

Evidence: Evidence from penetration test runs demonstrates detection of resource exhaustion vulnerabilities (Medium severity) identifying unbounded queries causing denial of service; dedicated action groups for unrestricted resource consumption testing.

Limitations: None identified for this specific requirement.

Additional Notes: The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis, testing invalid inputs and exception scenarios through multiple action groups.
A10: Mishandling of Exceptional Conditions
Failures in secure state handling
Covered
Description: AWS Security Agent provides coverage for failures in secure state handling. The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis.
Evidence: Evidence from penetration test runs demonstrates detection of registration atomicity failures (Medium severity) identifying failures that do not leave applications in secure states.

Limitations: None identified for this specific requirement.

Additional Notes: The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis, testing invalid inputs and exception scenarios.
A10: Mishandling of Exceptional Conditions
Data boundary condition validation
Covered
Description: AWS Security Agent provides coverage for data boundary condition validation. The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis.
Evidence: Evidence from penetration test runs demonstrates detection of data boundary condition issues (Medium severity) in currency calculations.

Limitations: None identified for this specific requirement.

Additional Notes: The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis, testing invalid inputs and exception scenarios.
A10: Mishandling of Exceptional Conditions
Input validation and sanitization at all system boundaries
Partial

Description: AWS Security Agent provides partial coverage for input validation and sanitization at all system boundaries. The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis.

Evidence: The service indirectly detects missing input validation and sanitization through injection vulnerability findings (A05), which demonstrate that user input is not properly validated or sanitized, allowing injection attacks. Multiple injection findings (SQL injection, command injection, code injection, XSS) indicate missing input validation and sanitization.

Limitations: The service does not specifically test whether inputs are validated for type, length, range, format, encoding, and allowed values at all system boundaries (UI/API/files/webhooks/queues). The service detects injection vulnerabilities that result from missing validation but does not comprehensively test all input validation requirements (type checking, length limits, range validation, format validation, encoding validation, allowed value lists) across all system entry points.

Additional Notes: The service indirectly detects missing input validation and sanitization through injection vulnerability findings (A05), which demonstrate that user input is not properly validated or sanitized, allowing injection attacks. However, the service does not specifically test whether inputs are validated for type, length, range, format, encoding, and allowed values at all system boundaries.
A10: Mishandling of Exceptional Conditions
Race condition testing
Not covered
Description: AWS Security Agent does not test for race conditions.
Evidence: No evidence of race condition testing found in penetration test runs.

Limitations: The service does not test for race conditions or concurrency issues, validate input sanitization at all system boundaries (covered indirectly through injection findings), test dependency/network failure handling, validate authentication/authorization under error conditions, test adverse environmental states, perform fault injection (dependency outages/timeouts, fuzzing), assess operational readiness for exceptional conditions, or assess whether applications define or inventory exceptional conditions.

Additional Notes: The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis, but does not test for race conditions or concurrency issues.
A10: Mishandling of Exceptional Conditions
Concurrency issue detection
Not covered
Description: AWS Security Agent does not detect concurrency issues.
Evidence: No evidence of concurrency issue detection found in penetration test runs.

Limitations: The service does not test for race conditions or concurrency issues, validate input sanitization at all system boundaries (covered indirectly through injection findings), test dependency/network failure handling, validate authentication/authorization under error conditions, test adverse environmental states, perform fault injection (dependency outages/timeouts, fuzzing), assess operational readiness for exceptional conditions, or assess whether applications define or inventory exceptional conditions.

Additional Notes: The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis, but does not test for race conditions or concurrency issues.
A10: Mishandling of Exceptional Conditions
Dependency/network failure handling
Not covered
Description: AWS Security Agent does not test dependency/network failure handling.
Evidence: No evidence of dependency/network failure handling testing found in penetration test runs.

Limitations: The service does not test for race conditions or concurrency issues, validate input sanitization at all system boundaries (covered indirectly through injection findings), test dependency/network failure handling, validate authentication/authorization under error conditions, test adverse environmental states, perform fault injection (dependency outages/timeouts, fuzzing), assess operational readiness for exceptional conditions, or assess whether applications define or inventory exceptional conditions.

Additional Notes: The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis, but does not simulate dependency outages/timeouts or perform fault injection.
A10: Mishandling of Exceptional Conditions
Authentication/authorization under error conditions
Not covered
Description: AWS Security Agent does not validate authentication/authorization under error conditions.
Evidence: No evidence of authentication/authorization validation under error conditions found in penetration test runs.

Limitations: The service does not test for race conditions or concurrency issues, validate input sanitization at all system boundaries (covered indirectly through injection findings), test dependency/network failure handling, validate authentication/authorization under error conditions, test adverse environmental states, perform fault injection (dependency outages/timeouts, fuzzing), assess operational readiness for exceptional conditions, or assess whether applications define or inventory exceptional conditions.

Additional Notes: The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis, but does not validate authentication/authorization under error conditions.
A10: Mishandling of Exceptional Conditions
Fault injection testing
Not covered
Description: AWS Security Agent does not perform fault injection testing.

Evidence: The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis, testing invalid inputs and exception scenarios through multiple action groups (SQL injection, command injection, code injection, XSS, business logic vulnerabilities). Code scanner tasks ("Code scanner [frameworks]", "Code scanner [important flows]", "Code scanner [business logic]") analyze code for vulnerabilities. However, the service does not simulate dependency outages/timeouts or perform fuzzing.

Limitations: The service does not test for race conditions or concurrency issues, validate input sanitization at all system boundaries (covered indirectly through injection findings), test dependency/network failure handling, validate authentication/authorization under error conditions, test adverse environmental states, perform fault injection (dependency outages/timeouts, fuzzing), assess operational readiness for exceptional conditions, or assess whether applications define or inventory exceptional conditions.

Additional Notes: The service tests for invalid inputs and exceptions but does not perform fault injection (e.g., simulating database connection failures, network timeouts, dependency service outages) or comprehensive fuzzing to discover edge cases in input parsing, deserialization, or file upload handling.
A10: Mishandling of Exceptional Conditions
Fuzzing of parsers/deserializers/uploads
Not covered
Description: AWS Security Agent does not perform fuzzing of parsers/deserializers/uploads.

Evidence: The service performs negative-path testing through penetration testing and static code analysis, testing invalid inputs and exception scenarios through multiple action groups. However, the service does not perform fuzzing of parsers/deserializers/uploads.

Limitations: The service does not test for race conditions or concurrency issues, validate input sanitization at all system boundaries (covered indirectly through injection findings), test dependency/network failure handling, validate authentication/authorization under error conditions, test adverse environmental states, perform fault injection (dependency outages/timeouts, fuzzing), assess operational readiness for exceptional conditions, or assess whether applications define or inventory exceptional conditions.

Additional Notes: The service tests for invalid inputs and exceptions but does not perform comprehensive fuzzing to discover edge cases in input parsing, deserialization, or file upload handling.

sections.title: Conclusion and Recommendations
paragraphs: AWS Security Agent represents a shift toward continuous, embedded application security. It automates design and code reviews, runs realistic multi‑step penetration tests and centralizes findings, enabling teams to identify issues earlier and reduce manual effort. The service's context‑aware approach, custom security requirements and multi‑step attack simulations are valuable features.

However, the preview version has notable limitations: it is available only in one region, requires manual configuration through a web interface, supports only private GitHub repositories, lacks scheduling and API automation (scheduled testing is explicitly documented as unavailable [9]), and cannot handle complex exploitation scenarios or non‑HTTP protocols. Only GitHub integration is supported; other SCM systems (GitLab, Bitbucket, CodeCommit) are not available [3]. Regarding OWASP Top 10 coverage, AWS Security Agent demonstrates significant variation across risk categories: Injection (A05) achieves complete coverage at 100%, followed by Broken Access Control (A01) at 87.5%, Security Misconfiguration (A02) at 62.5%, Insecure Design (A06) at 60.0%, Mishandling of Exceptional Conditions (A10) at 45.8%, Authentication Failures (A07) at 41.7%, Cryptographic Failures (A04) at 30.0%, Software or Data Integrity Failures (A08) at 27.8%, Security Logging and Alerting Failures (A09) at 15.0%, and Software Supply Chain Failures (A03) at 0.0%. The service provides strong coverage for injection vulnerabilities and access control, moderate coverage for security misconfiguration and insecure design, but has significant gaps in software supply chain security, cryptographic validation beyond TLS checks, logging and alerting, and data integrity failures. To fully secure their applications, organizations should use AWS Security Agent as a complementary control alongside additional tools and processes (e.g., dependency scanning, secrets management, infrastructure‑as‑code security, and runtime monitoring) and maintain human expertise for nuanced assessments.

references.title: What is AWS Security Agent? - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation describing key capabilities (design security review, code security review, penetration testing), benefits (on-demand accessibility, automatic validation of organizational requirements, scalable security expertise, actionable fixes, multi and hybrid cloud support), and how the service operates across the development lifecycle. The documentation states that the agent provides design reviews, code security reviews and multi‑step penetration testing within a centralized web interface.

references.title: AWS Security Agent (Preview): AI agent for proactive app security
references.description: AWS What's New announcement from December 2, 2025, announcing the preview of AWS Security Agent, an AI-powered agent that proactively secures applications throughout the development lifecycle. The announcement describes automated security reviews, context-aware penetration testing, and validation from design to deployment.

references.title: Review code security findings in GitHub - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation explaining how code review works in GitHub, including that code review is triggered when a pull request is marked as "Ready for review" and that draft pull requests are not analyzed

references.title: New AWS Security Agent secures applications proactively from design to deployment (preview)
references.description: AWS News Feed post summarising features including automated design, code and penetration tests, context awareness and OWASP Top 10 code checks

references.title: Service Quotas - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation listing service quotas including operations quotas (pentest hours: 80/month, design reviews: 200/month, code reviews: 1,000/month) and configuration quotas (integrations: 20 per account per region, integrated resources per integration: 20, custom security requirements: 20 per account per region, concurrent pentest runs: 5 per account per region)

references.title: Create a penetration test - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation describing how to create penetration tests, including prerequisites, configuration of test scope, target domains (only verified domains can be tested), VPC resources (only required for private applications), authentication credentials, and additional resources

references.title: AWS Debuts Security Agent for Automated Code-Level Protection
references.description: National CIO Review article noting that AWS Security Agent automates penetration testing tailored to application design and code

references.title: AWS targets vulnerable code with security agent
references.description: ComputerWeekly report highlighting that AWS Security Agent continuously scans for security violations, conducts on‑demand penetration tests and ties security across the development lifecycle

references.title: Security Considerations for AWS Security Agent and AI assisted penetration testing - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation on security considerations, explicitly stating that AWS Security Agent does not have public APIs or the ability to schedule penetration test runs

references.title: Security best practices for AWS Security Agent - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation on security best practices, including code repository access limitations stating that AWS Security Agent does not provide code security guidance for public repositories

references.title: Connect agent to private VPC resources - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation on connecting the agent to private VPC resources, explicitly stating that VPC CIDR ranges that overlap with the 10.0.0.0/16 range are currently not supported for VPC penetration tests

references.title: Infrastructure security in AWS Security Agent - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation on infrastructure security, stating that AWS Security Agent requires internet access to perform penetration testing on target applications and for control plane operations

references.title: OWASP Top 10:2025
references.description: OWASP Top 10:2025 list of application security risks
